pr_title: Implementation of a JWT-based OAuth2 flow for the admin API

timeline.message:
Initial implementation of a JWT-based OAuth2 flow for the admin API

Implements #1388.

Signed-off-by: Yannick Schaus <github@schaus.net>

Improve token issuing & session management

- Allow the use of a support cookie to mitigate leaking
of refresh tokens stored in the browser with XSS
attacks. The flow is still OAuth2 but the client can
make the server set an http-only cookie with the
session ID, which will be checked when the refresh
token is used to get another access token.
This cookie can also be used for certain servlets
(/proxy, /icon...) without an access_token to get
the user session, if the risks of CSRF are acceptable.

- Prevent leaking exceptions to the client when the token
is invalid

- Improve logging

- Detect api_key query parameters from the swagger UI

- Improvements to the authorize page: confirm the password
when creating the first account, sanitize some user input,
improve messages

- Add logout (session removal) endpoint

- Add checks yo improve conformity to RFC 6749

- Adjust some RoleAllowed annotations

- Reduce JWS key size from RS512 to RS256

Signed-off-by: Yannick Schaus <github@schaus.net>

Add support for PKCE (RFC 7636)

Support X-OPENHAB-TOKEN headers as alternative header
for the token if the X-OPENHAB-AUTH-HEADER is set
(whatever its value). This is helpful when the
Authorization header is already used by a reverse
proxy or openHAB Cloud/myopenhab.org. It can then
set a X-OPENHAB-AUTH-HEADER cookie which must be
visible to the JavaScript (i.e. no HttpOnly) which
should then pass the token in the alternative header.

timeline.bodyText:
Hm, theoretically, you would need to keep track of this per user - otherwise, other users would not be able to login if a certain user forgot his password and did too many tries.
For our openHAB situation, it could be ok to block log in in general, though as we are not talking about many different user accounts.
timeline.author: kaikreuzer

replies.bodyText: That's what I thought too, to keep things simple. As a "last resort" restarting the bundle (or openHAB) does reset the timer too.
replies.author: ghys

timeline.bodyText: Will you evaluate this somehow in the UI? How will the user know that he is merely temporarily blocked for a few seconds? Maybe we could simply add that info ("Login possible again after x seconds" or something like that).
timeline.author: kaikreuzer

replies.bodyText: It only says "Please try again" to the user but the real reason is logged as a warning so you would see "Authentication failed: Too many consecutive login attempts" in the logs. Isn't is enough?
replies.author: ghys

replies.bodyText: A "Please try again" does not tell the user much. But as I assume that a normal user won't misspell his password more than 3 times in a row, he won't really hit the delay at all - and for brute force attackers, I don't care what message they see ;-)
replies.author: kaikreuzer

replies.bodyText: Yes, in some schools of thought it's considered a good practice to remain rather opaque on what the actual issue is when the login fails - i.e. not tell that the user account actually exists but the password is wrong, or if the account is locked for some reason. It doesn't scale well when you have thousands of accounts but I believe we're not in that situation with openHAB so it's fine to look at the logs to figure out why a otherwise legitimate login didn't succeed ;)
replies.author: ghys
